question:
who wrote i want to dance with somebody by whitney houston
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
"I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" is a popular song performed by Whitney Houston. To determine who wrote the song, I need to recall the songwriters associated with it. The song was released in 1987 and became one of Houston's signature hits. The songwriters for "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" are George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam, who were part of the duo Boy Meets Girl. 

Answer: George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam.

who wrote i want to dance with somebody by whitney houston

['"I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" is the first single from Whitney Houston\'s second studio album, "Whitney". It was released on May 2, 1987 by Arista Records. It was produced by Narada Michael Walden, and written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam, of the band Boy Meets Girl, who had previously written the number-one Whitney Houston hit "How Will I Know."\n', '"I Wanna Dance with Somebody" was written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam, who wrote Houston\'s 1985 song "How Will I Know, which became successful, and as a result, they were asked to come up with another song for Houston\'s then-new album. Originally the song that gave Merrill and Rubicam their British top ten success as Boy Meets Girl, "Waiting For a Star to Fall" was intended by the duo to be a song for Houston. The duo sent it to Arista Records, but they passed on it citing it was not suitable for Houston. Undeterred by this minor setback, the pair continued working on finding a song that would be ideal for Houston, and were inspired to come up with "I Wanna Dance with Somebody." Later on, Rubicam explained the idea behind the song:\n', 'Houston released her second studio album, "Whitney", on April 27, 1987. The album became the first by a female artist to debut atop the US "Billboard" 200 album chart, a position it held for 11 weeks. "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" was released as the lead single from "Whitney". The dance-pop song was written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam. It was ranked at number 88 on Slant Magazine\'s list of the 100 Greatest Dance Songs in 2006. "I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me)", along with the following three singles to be released from "Whitney", ("Didn\'t We Almost Have It All", "So Emotional" and "Where Do Broken Hearts Go"), all peaked at number one on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 singles chart; as of August 2013, Houston holds for the record for the most consecutive number one singles on the chart, with seven. Her third studio album, "I\'m Your Baby Tonight", was released on November 2, 1990. It was decided by her record label executive, Clive Davis at Arista Records, that Houston should grow as an artist and develop her music further by making an R&B album instead of another pop music album. Davis enlisted L.A. Reid and Babyface to compose more R&B driven songs. The title track was released as the lead single from the album, and it was written by Reid and Babyface. It topped the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. The second single, "All the Man That I Need", is an "expression of sexual hero worship" according to Stephen Holden writing for "The New York Times".\n', 'BULLET::::- Whitney Houston - "I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me)" (1987)\n', 'BULLET::::- Whitney Houston – "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)"\n', 'BULLET::::- Whitney Houston - "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)"\n', 'BULLET::::1. **Expert Discussion on "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" by Whitney Houston**

**Expert 1: Music Historian**
"I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" is a significant piece in Whitney Houston's discography, marking her transition into the late '80s pop scene. Written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam, it showcases their ability to craft catchy, danceable tunes that resonate with audiences. The song's release as the lead single from her second studio album, "Whitney," was a strategic move that solidified her status as a pop icon.

**Expert 2: Lyricist and Songwriter**
From a songwriting perspective, Merrill and Rubicam's collaboration on this track is fascinating. They had previously written "How Will I Know," which was a major hit for Houston. The duo's creative process involved responding to the success of their earlier work with Houston, demonstrating how artists and songwriters often build on past successes to create new hits. Their inspiration for "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" reflects a desire to capture the joy and excitement of love, which is a universal theme in pop music.

**Expert 3: Cultural Critic**
Culturally, this song represents more than just a dance hit; it encapsulates the spirit of the 1980s. The upbeat tempo and infectious chorus invite listeners to celebrate love and connection, which resonates with the era's emphasis on personal expression and freedom. Houston's powerful vocal delivery further elevates the song, making it an anthem for many. The song's success also highlights the role of female artists in shaping pop music during this time.

**Expert 4: Music Industry Analyst**
From an industry perspective, the song's release strategy was pivotal. Clive Davis, the head of Arista Records, recognized Houston's potential and positioned her to dominate the charts. The fact that "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" became one of her most recognizable songs speaks to the effectiveness of this strategy. It not only topped the charts but also contributed to Houston's legacy as one of the most successful female artists in music history.

**Points of Agreement:**
All experts agree on the significance of "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" in Whitney Houston's career and its impact on pop music. They recognize the songwriting prowess of Merrill and Rubicam and the strategic decisions made by Clive Davis that contributed to the song's success. Additionally, there is a consensus on the cultural relevance of the song, particularly in the context of the 1980s.

**Points of Disagreement:**
While there is general agreement on the song's importance, the experts differ in their emphasis on various aspects. The music historian focuses on the historical context, while the lyricist emphasizes the songwriting process. The cultural critic highlights the song's broader societal implications, whereas the industry analyst concentrates on the commercial strategies behind its success.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The discussion reveals that "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" is not just a pop hit; it is a multifaceted work that reflects the collaborative nature of music creation, the cultural zeitgeist of the 1980s, and the strategic maneuvers of the music industry. The song's enduring popularity can be attributed to its catchy melody, relatable lyrics, and Whitney Houston's powerful performance, all of which combined to create a timeless anthem that continues to resonate with audiences today.

In summary, the collaborative insights from the experts deepen our understanding of the song by highlighting its artistic, cultural, and commercial significance, illustrating how "I Wanna Dance with Somebody" remains a landmark in both Whitney Houston's career and the broader landscape of pop music.

question_info.question: who wrote i want to dance with somebody by whitney houston
passages:
"I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" is the first single from Whitney Houston's second studio album, "Whitney". It was released on May 2, 1987 by Arista Records. It was produced by Narada Michael Walden, and written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam, of the band Boy Meets Girl, who had previously written the number-one Whitney Houston hit "How Will I Know."
"I Wanna Dance with Somebody" was written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam, who wrote Houston's 1985 song "How Will I Know, which became successful, and as a result, they were asked to come up with another song for Houston's then-new album. Originally the song that gave Merrill and Rubicam their British top ten success as Boy Meets Girl, "Waiting For a Star to Fall" was intended by the duo to be a song for Houston. The duo sent it to Arista Records, but they passed on it citing it was not suitable for Houston. Undeterred by this minor setback, the pair continued working on finding a song that would be ideal for Houston, and were inspired to come up with "I Wanna Dance with Somebody." Later on, Rubicam explained the idea behind the song:
Houston released her second studio album, "Whitney", on April 27, 1987. The album became the first by a female artist to debut atop the US "Billboard" 200 album chart, a position it held for 11 weeks. "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)" was released as the lead single from "Whitney". The dance-pop song was written by George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam. It was ranked at number 88 on Slant Magazine's list of the 100 Greatest Dance Songs in 2006. "I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me)", along with the following three singles to be released from "Whitney", ("Didn't We Almost Have It All", "So Emotional" and "Where Do Broken Hearts Go"), all peaked at number one on the US "Billboard" Hot 100 singles chart; as of August 2013, Houston holds for the record for the most consecutive number one singles on the chart, with seven. Her third studio album, "I'm Your Baby Tonight", was released on November 2, 1990. It was decided by her record label executive, Clive Davis at Arista Records, that Houston should grow as an artist and develop her music further by making an R&B album instead of another pop music album. Davis enlisted L.A. Reid and Babyface to compose more R&B driven songs. The title track was released as the lead single from the album, and it was written by Reid and Babyface. It topped the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. The second single, "All the Man That I Need", is an "expression of sexual hero worship" according to Stephen Holden writing for "The New York Times".
